message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest bacterial conjunctivitis. Topical erythromycin can treat bacterial conjunctivitis whereas topical natamycin and topical prednisolone acetate are used to treat fungal and allergic conjunctivitis, respectively. Oral erythromycin may be an option, but topical therapy is more appropriate for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and ophthalmic examination suggest bacterial conjunctivitis. Among the options, only topical erythromycin is an appropriate treatment for bacterial conjunctivitis. Topical natamycin is used for fungal keratitis, topical prednisolone acetate is a steroid and may worsen the infection, and oral erythromycin is not as effective and may have more side effects than topical erythromycin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest bacterial conjunctivitis, which is usually treated with topical antibiotics. Among the options, topical erythromycin is the most appropriate choice for bacterial conjunctivitis. Topical natamycin is used to treat fungal infections of the eye, while topical prednisolone acetate is a corticosteroid used to treat inflammation. Oral erythromycin may be used for severe cases, but topical treatment is preferred as it reduces systemic side effects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest bacterial conjunctivitis, which is best treated with topical antibiotics. Of the options, topical erythromycin is the most appropriate. Topical natamycin is used to treat fungal infections of the eye. Topical prednisolone acetate is a corticosteroid and should not be used unless there is accompanying inflammation. Oral erythromycin is not necessary for this localized infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest conjunctivitis, and the presence of yellow crusts indicate bacterial infection. Among the options, only topical erythromycin is used to treat bacterial conjunctivitis. Topical natamycin is used to treat fungal infections, while topical prednisolone acetate is a corticosteroid used to treat inflammation. Oral erythromycin can also be used to treat bacterial conjunctivitis, but topical administration is preferred.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and ophthalmic examination suggest bacterial conjunctivitis. Among the options, only topical erythromycin is an appropriate pharmacotherapy for bacterial conjunctivitis. Topical natamycin is used for fungal conjunctivitis, while topical prednisolone acetate is a corticosteroid used for non-infectious conjunctivitis. Oral erythromycin may be used in severe cases, but topical therapy is preferred.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest bacterial conjunctivitis, and the most appropriate pharmacotherapy is topical antibiotics such as erythromycin. Topical prednisolone acetate may be used for allergic conjunctivitis, but it is not indicated here. Topical natamycin is used for fungal keratitis, which is not indicated here. Oral erythromycin may be used for severe bacterial infections but is not the first-line treatment for bacterial conjunctivitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest bacterial conjunctivitis, and topical antibiotics would be the most appropriate pharmacotherapy. Of the options provided, topical erythromycin is the most appropriate choice. Natamycin is used for fungal infections of the eye, prednisolone acetate is a steroid and should not be used alone for bacterial infections, and oral erythromycin is not necessary for mild bacterial conjunctivitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest bacterial conjunctivitis, and topical erythromycin is the most appropriate treatment. Topical natamycin is used to treat fungal keratitis. Topical prednisolone acetate is used to treat inflammatory eye conditions, but it can exacerbate viral and bacterial infections. Oral erythromycin is not necessary for this localized infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest bacterial conjunctivitis, and among the options, topical erythromycin is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this condition. Topical natamycin is used for fungal keratitis, topical prednisolone acetate is used for allergic conjunctivitis, and oral erythromycin is not necessary for the treatment of bacterial conjunctivitis.
